bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, August 30, 1911

div1.p: Kean denies a rumor that he has been chosen to succeed General Torney. He informs Gorgas that the 10th Infantry has been ordered to Panama.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, August 30, 1911
div1.opener:
CONFIDENTIAL
B
August 30,1911.
My dear Gorgas:
div1.p:
In my letter to you of Sunday, replying to yours about your in-
tentions as to the succession, I forgot to mention a hot-air letter that
Edie wrote to Ireland from the Isthmus, in which he said that a rumor was
going about there to the effect that I had come to an agreement with
General Torney by which he was going to retire when his present appointment
was up and push me as the successor. I want to say that there is not the
faintest shadow of truth in this. I wish there was. No word of conversa-
tion has ever passed between us on the subject of the successor, and I have
not the faintest idea that he will be willing to give up his position until
June, 1814, when he reaches the age of sixty-four.

Since writing you it has occurred to me that you may have heard
this, and it might have had some connection with your letter to me, and I am
somewhat curious to know if this is a fact.

The 10th Infantry has been ordered to Panama, and I understand from
the Surgeon General that no provision has yet been made for the care of their
sick. I suppose, however, that you will see that they are looked after.
Please remember me very cordially to Mrs. Gorgas.
div1.closer:
Your friend, sincerely, Kean Col. William C. Gorgas,
Medical Corps,
Ancon,
Panama.
